sp.p: No, no, that's enough in all Conſcience; for you Sparks are large Promiſers, that I know, but bad Performers, or the Women fouly bely you: But conſider on't, Gentlemen, a Thouſand Pound a Man will be fair on all ſides.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That I'll give thee freely, for my part, if the Sale of my wretched Annuity can raiſe it; here's my Hand, ſhalt have all farther Security I can give thee.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: O Lack-a-day! Sir, you're a Man of Honour— Come, Mr. Wild-man, what ſay you? Will you follow your Leader, and leave the Merchants their Goods to ſolder up their Cracks.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, if it muſt be ſo, tho' I confeſs—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I'd have you make as cheap a Bargain as may be, eſpecially for Goods that may ſtand you, poſſibly, but in little ſtead. Women, you know, are changeable.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Madam.
What Bear-like Entertainment is this! a ſnap of Comfort, and a polt on the Pate.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Come, Sir, come, I'm in pain till I have diſcharg'd my Truſt.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, Patience; What, give the Gentleman leave to conſider a little.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's needleſs, Madam; for tho' I have felt the Severity of your Diſdain, yet your Honour I never call'd in queſtion.
Come, Trulove's my Security, if you queſtion my own.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I am, I am; come, prithee, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, no, I'll—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No, no, but you ſhan't; fair and ſoftly, by your Leave, Sir. Think not that a trifling Summ, which here is one will ſhare, has induc'd me to this: Know, Sir, 'tis the Honour of the Deed, and that I'll reſerve entire to my ſelf; the Honour and Danger ſhall be mine, and mine alone.
By your Leave, Madam, let me peep into your Stomacher.
So, here a comes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let's ſee't, let's ſee't.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Three moments Patience, Mr. Wildman, and then— Hey toſs! what have we got here? Mynheer van dunc van dunc Vanduncart's Bond, I think— Pho pox! 'tis a Dutch Man's Bond, not worth a Butterom.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Now! now!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Three Moments Patience, Gentlemen, and then— Hum—

A Settlement upon my Man Jonathan of Twenty Pounds per Annum, after my Deceaſe. Griping Dog! What intended he to do with the reſt? Sure he has ſome Correſpondence in Hell, that he deſigns to draw Bills upon.
Faith, Sir, I ſee 'em on the right ſide of the Stile, as it happens.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, no more preaching; you'll tire my Patience preſently.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Come Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Coming, coming, Sir. (Tumbles the Papers.) Oh! have I caught you? (Stands up, ſhuts the Box, and puts his Foot out.) Hum, hum, hum. (Reads.) My Brother Sir Roger's Settlement upon Niece Lettice. Ha! Sir, is this it?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ay, honeſt Jonathan, this, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Here, Sir.
And give you Joy, Madam.
And there's two; for when the Man has the Fortune, the Woman's his of Courſe.
Here, Sir, here's your Honoria's as cloſe as —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, no more Similies, but to work; let's ſee what elſe.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Elſe! What i'th' the Name of Balzebub would you have elſe? You'd make the Devil of a Farmer— Crop and Gleanings too! Why, i'th' Name of Avarice, won't a Thouſand Pound (points to Let.) a Year, beſides ſo neat, tight, convenient a Pleaſure-Houſe upon it, ſerve turn? Enough, Enough—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: In all Conſcience, but only Curioſity—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nay, I muſt confeſs that's a plaguy itching Diſtemper. But if you want a Raſp, a Rubber, or a Scratcher, (points to Let.) ſhe'll—

sp.speaker: Omnes, preter. Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To th' Trunk, you Dog, and ceaſe barking, or—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, I'd have you to know I am none of your barking Currs: Indeed, I do bite ſometimes; I have Teeth, Sir, as ſhall appear when you'll give me leave to employ 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, make an end; for I ſee you will be the Diſturber.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, you ſee I love to diſtribute my Favours.
sp.stage: Goes to the Trunk, and ſtumbles over it, rubbing his Shins and Noſe.
sp.p: Madam Letitia! cry your Mercy— Pox on't, I thought it had been her by my Noſe and Shins.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hellhound! let me come at him.
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sirrah, diſpatch, or I'll be gone, and leave you to his Mercy.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nay, then it's time to be ſerious.
I muſt diſpatch before Afternoon's Luncheon-time, or he'll have the whip hand of me, and make me languiſh till Supper.
sp.stage: Jon. pulls out ſeveral Papers, ſlings 'em by ſlightly, while he ſings.

lg.l: And when I was a little Boy I waſh'd my Mother's Diſhes,
I put my Fingers in the Pail, and pull'd out little Fiſhes.

sp.p: (Pulling and heaving.) Ho, up, Maſs. This ſhould be a ſwinger by the weight and gills. (Pulls out a Parchment, with Labels.) If this been't a Deed of weight, the Devil's in't. Oh— (Reads.) Securities for the Thouſand Pound left by my Brother Sir Roger to — (Overturns the Trunk.) Here, take 'em among you, for I've neither Encouragement nor Patience to ſtay any longer. Oons, here's Money enough to redeem the City Charter— Save ye, Gentlemen; and pray remember the Civility-Money.
sp.stage: As he is going out, enters Lurcher, who over-runs him almoſt.
sp.p: S bud, you blind Mill Horſe, can't you ſee where you ſtumble?

sp.speaker: Eurcher.
sp.p: Make off, Gentlemen, and Ladies, all of you; here's Sir Fickle coming this way, and in a damn'd bad Humour, I can tell you ſo much.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nay, then, all Friends, come all Hands aloft.
sp.stage: They put in all the Papers, except one left on the Stage, Jon. takes the Trunk.
sp.p: Away, away there, here a comes, and in a plaguy Chafe I'll warrant him, or elſe he wears no Socks to Day, I ſmell that alleady.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Well, now Sir Fickle you're like to be fitted with a young, brisk, gallant Lady— Marry ſend you good Luck, for 'tis a ſhrewd Undertaking for one of your Years and Conſtitution; and let me tell you ſo much, Sir, there are many in better Circumſtances than your ſelf that would be plaguily affraid of ſore Eyes for all their Golden Thumb Rings. Well, Look afore you leap, And what's done can't be recover'd, are Proverbial Saws as old as Alderſgate, therefore, methinks, 'twere worth Time to conſider— Hum! She's young, I (Coughing.) o-o-old as her Grannum: She's brisk; ay, pox! brisk enough, enough, and too much for me. Then for her Gallantry, the Girl, I percieve, is pretty well inclin'd; and, for all her Country Breeding, would make ſhift, in a very reaſonable time, to reduce the Eaſt-India Stock into a Pedlar's Pack. Hum, methinks our two Qualities agree like Dogs-Turd and Honey; and I ſhould be moſt plaguily deceiv'd, if, inſtead of a Lenitive for the Spleen, I ſhould meet with a Cauſtick for a ſore Throat. Well, I'll to Council; two Heads are better than one, as Neighbour Wrangle ſays, and all the City acknowledge him for the Pro-po-potatripes, I think they call him, of Learning and Sence. Well, I'll to Graves's, this is the Hour of Audience; if I can but meet with him in the Humour of talking Sence in Engliſh, he'll diſpatch me in as few Words as a Lawyer his Client that comes to him in Forma Pauperis.

div.head: SCENE Changes.
div.stage: Enter Wrangle, Soberſides, Fickle aloof off.

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Fool! Blockhead! Incomprehenſible Dolt! Thou Ox in an Aſs's Skin!

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Oh here he is, and Neighbour Soberſides too! piping hot from the Coffee-Houſe, I'll warrant 'em, by the profoundneſs of their Talk.

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Get you gone to School again, and learn the Meaning of the Word Ratification befor you pretend to diſpute the Legality or Eſſential Formality, requiſite to the Conſtitution thereof; for I tell you once more, thou impertinent Head-piece, Ignoratis terminis, Ignoratur & ars!

sp.speaker: Fickle,
sp.p: Oh, I underſtand this a little.
Ay, ay, Sir, ſo he is an ignorant termegant Aſs, to pretend to argue with you that can read, write, and Latin— But I come, Sir, to adviſe with, not to diſpute, your Wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Dilate energically, conciſely, and uninaegmatically.
Oph.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Sir—
Pox! now his Learning has got the upper-hand of his Sence, there will be no underſtanding of his cramp Language for Men of my Capacity— Sir, I did not underſtand—

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Oh ye pellucid Stars! whoſe Influences are ſubſervient to Sapience, deconglommerate me from theſe unzodiacal, uncerebrated, circumambient Gemini.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Nay, an he be got up to the Stars already, O Gemini too ſay I — Save you, Sir, and pray give me notice of the next Thunder; I have a Stock of Beer in my Celler.
sp.stage: As he is going out, Wrangle ſiezes him.

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Arreſt! (Fickle ſtarts.) I will deſcend, the Gods themſelves have deign'd to cope with Mortals.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: With Grocers, Sir!

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: With their Inferiors far, with Milkmaids! Europa was one, Jove courted her in the Shape of a Bull, and had Iſſue by her, a Proginy of Cuckolds, autockthonical, aboriginal, demi-deify'd Cuckolds.

p.hi: O Felices nimium ſi ſua bona norint!

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: A pretty Account, Faith, of the Riſe of Cuckoldom, a Bull, and a Milk-maid! Doubtleſs hence come the Proverb of ſucking a Bull— But, Sir, be pleas'd to hear my Sence of—

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Sir, I tell you both Sence or no Sence, Ratification is an Overt Subſequent Act to a Precedent Covert Tranſaction.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Overt! Covert! Precedent! and Subſequent! What Trade do theſe Terms of Art belong to? What a Devil, do you banter? Or are you a conjuring?

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: I'll be plain: For Example, I owe you a Grudge; that's a Covert, or Secret Tranſaction in my Mind.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: Then (Kicks and cuffs him.) This is an Open, Publick, or Overt Act or Declaration thereof— Now I hope you underſtand this is demonſtrative.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: O moſt ſenſibly, Sir.
Pox on him! I could give him a Suit of Second Mourning too, as Wildman ſays, for Example's ſake, but that he's ſuch a Royſter.

sp.speaker: Wrang. to Soberſ.
sp.p: And you, I hope, have your Intellectuals meliorated when this— (Points to Fickle.)
This, what, Sir? This, what? I'd have you to know I'm in as fair a way both to a Chain and a Clog as—

sp.speaker: Wrang.
sp.p: But I loſe time 'mongſt a Brace of Owls.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Owls! Pox, Owls! Owls in your Throat, Sir; Owls in your Belly, Sir; Owls in your— Pantiples, Sir. Pox! if hard Words, dry Blows, and Affronts, be all the Counſel I muſt expect, Exit my Riddle-me-ree, Exit. (Turning him out.)

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: (Fickle at the ſame time.) Then will I leave you, as I found you, obfuſcated by Poetick Dulneſs and Palpable Calliginoſity.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Bur-r-r, Buz-z-z, Gingiber & Lacer Cicer Pepper atque Papaver. (Turns him out.) Owls! Pox, Owls! I don't know but I may be as good a Scholar as himſelf. Pox! I begin to—

sp.speaker: Wrangle.
sp.p: And Cimerian Tenebroſity.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p:
Hey! here again with his Tenebroſity? Hey, Noun, (Runs to him.) Pronoun, Prepoſition, Conjunction, Participle, Interjection; Haec aquila, an Owl, both he and ſhe. (Like an Owl runs at him.) Or-ro-o-o-o-o-o— (Looking after him.) Huzza! Victoria! So, 'tis but a little Reſolution, and theſe Roarers are ſoon tam'd. (Spying Soberſides.) O, Sir, cry vour Mercv.
This ſame paſſionate Puppy has ſo what-ye-call't my Intellectuals, I proteſt, I over-look'd you.

sp.speaker: Soberſ.
sp.p: That might be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: So it might, I vow, Sir. Now ſhall I be as much plagu'd with this Fellow's formal Preciſeneſs, as I was with the t'other's bluſtering Bombaſt— Deliver me but from this Piece of ſtiffn'd Tiffany, and if ever I go to Counſel to a citizen again, may he take my Noſe and Ears for his Fee.
But Sir.

sp.speaker: Sob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what I intended to have diſcours'd this ſame taſty, old, poſitive Puppy about, was Matrimony; I'm a going to be married to a brisk, young Country Virgin, her Fortune, it's true, is but ſmall, but my Inclinations are great; you know me, let me know your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sob.
sp.p: That I believe I ſhall give you; but firſt, by way of Advice, reprehend not that Poſitiveneſs in another, whereof you ſeem to be ſo well provided; for you ſeem poſitively to affirm that you are going to be married, which, if you conſider the Mutability of ſublunary things, I eſteem that you might with more Modeſty ſay, that you conceive, or think, judge, or ſuppoſe your ſelf upon the Matrimonial Point.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: The Man's in the right on't there; for we're fartheſt off ſometimes, when we think our ſelves neareſt to the Blank: And I remember, Neighbour Horner going once to view a She-Tenement he was about purchaſing, found a Copy-holder making forcible Entry into the capital Meſſuage of the Mannor, and ſo flew off; and Reaſon good, was it not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sob.
sp.p: Not unlikely— Then, Sir, as for her Briskneſs, it may poſſibly be Levity; her Youth artificial, and her Vertue and Virginity as ſlender as her Fortune.

sp.speaker: Fickle,
sp.p: How, Sir! No Vertue! No Virginity!

sp.speaker: Sob.
sp.p: Poſſibly none; for I am of the Sect of the Scepticks, I think, I affirm nothing.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: But I am not, and do poſitively ſay that Man's a Villain that dare call her Honour in queſtion; therefore, Sir Dubious, pick up your Awls, or, now my Hand's in, I can promiſe you no better Entertainment than your Deconglomerating Predeceſſor; th' Example's freſh, my Paſſion riſes; therefore once more walk off, or I ſhall Overtly ratifie upon your Morrion.

sp.speaker: Sob.
sp.p: Fortune I contemn, Examples I defie, and will maintain my Opinion, ſpight of Paſſion or Ratification.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Nay, Pox, if you begin to be poſitive, walk, walk, my Philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Sob.
sp.p: I'll have Satisfaction for this Affront done to my Perſon and Opinion; I'll be reveng'd, look to it.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: No, no, you only conceive, think, ſuppoſe, or believe ſo: Ha, ha, what a pair of Iſſaker's Aſſes have I turn'd out to Graſs! That Men ſhould be ſuch Fools, as to believe that a hard Word, or myſterial Nod, ſhould be the only Ingredients to the making up of a wiſe Man! Tho', I muſt confeſs, this ſame Scipſtick Philoſopher has put twenty Cunnundrums into my Head. Well, Time will clear all; therefore Patience, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, Wildman, whither wou'd you draw me? Come, you'll ne'er forget your old Tricks.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Ha, old Tricks! and ſo familiar— I'll retire, this Spark may inform me better than Old Sir Grandſire Grey-beard, with his Scythe and Hour-Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, never ſear, I've had enough of that ſame hoity toity Buſineſs; I come to read you a far different Leſſon, for you have been plaguily out of late; and for all your Philoſopher's Stone you brag of, Lettice has diſcover'd you to be but of baſe Allay: I gad, ſhould the Old Man diſcover the Counterfeit, you may e'n ſhift for your ſelf; I have done my part every way, if you ſpoil all, your Ruine be upon you; I waſh my Hands of it and you: My Mind's chang'd with my Fortune, and I'm reſolv'd hereafter to feed upon one Diſh; 'tis wholſomeſt, you know.

sp.speaker: Fickle,
sp.p: A good Beginning, truly! Where will this end, trow?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: For that matter as you pleaſe; I believe you may find Employment enough at Home. If my Cornuted Cully to be has too much, if his kind Neighbour will but lend him a hand, they'll find me both Reaſonable and Civil.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: A very civil Reſolution indeed! Oh, my Head! My Horns are cutting already.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That as you can agree, mean while be more circumſpect; when you have ſpring'd the Woodcock, why then cook him to your Palate; he's ready plum'd to your Hand, ſo much I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Plum'd! What mean you?

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Ay, that, that, my Heart miſgives me moſt confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No Queſtions, for Safety ſake. Women ought to be truſted with Secrets, as Mad Folks with Daggers; you may give 'em the Scabbard to pleaſe 'em, but be ſure to keep the Weapon cloſe and faſt. (Treads upon a Paper.) So, what have we here? Some Grocer's Bill, I'll warrant ir. (Takes it up, and looks on it.) No, Faith, 'tis Vanduncart's Bond.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Left out for haſt, in the laſt Surprize; I wiſh there he no more: For tho' I'm pretty ſure of my Point, yet things are not yet ripe enough for a Diſcovery. Let's ſee. (Looking about, ſpies Sir Fickle, who makes up to him.)

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Hem, hem; yours, Sir, yours.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you're a diligent Courtier. Indeed, were you not a truebred Engliſhman; one would take this for Italian Jealouſie, but 'tis too ſoon for that Man, ha?

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Why, truly, Sir, I am ſomewhat of a different Opinion, as a Man may ſay; I think it is rather of the lateſt; for—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Right too; for when things are ſo far advanc'd, Jealouſie's as unſeaſonable as a Song or Dance brought in Head and Shoulders, to lengthen out or ſet off a ſcanty-witted Bear-Play.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Gently, gently, Sir; not ſo neither. My Farce is but a Rehearſing, and I find it ſo far below my Expectation, I'm affraid to venture it on the Theatre, for fear of being hiſs'd off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Devil's in him, ſure— Sir, you're myſterions; pray, be plain.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Why then moſt plainly thus: My Love, Thanks to my Years, has been ſo moderate as to leave me ſome few of my Senſes, with which I have conſider'd, that at the beſt 'tis but Folly, but in old Men meer Dotage. I find all other Paſſions encreaſing, this only dwindl'd to nothing, which makes me judge my ſelf unfit for a Lady of her Qualities. Theſe, and ſome other private ones, have abated the Violence of my Frenſie, and inſpir'd into me the Reſolution of gaining in Statu quo, as a Man may ſay, till I ſee better Reaſons for a Change— Now I hope you're both ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh my Heart!

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Oh my Head a!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Satisfy'd! No, but I will expect it
For all th'Affronts you've put upon my Couſin,
Poor tho' in Fortune, yet in Vertue rich;
For all thoſe Tears, thou ſtony-hearted Beaſt!
Your Barbarity now cauſes her to ſhed.
Her Preſence now protects you from my Rage.
But ſet a better Price on Innocence,
Or Fell Revenge ſhall follow you with ſpeed.
Come, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll prevent that; I'll ſwear the Peace againſt him: Firſt, for endeavouring to top his Whore upon me; and then for threatning to Fell me. If I don't, believe her honeſt. Many a Man has cut a Caper, and never come down alive again, for leſs than this, that's certain. I'll trounce the ſly Dog; I'll bind him to his good Behaviour, I will a— O plague of the Devil! now I talk of binding, the Bond! the Bond! how come that there? I'm ſure it was in the Trunk I entruſted Jonathan with. I gad, if he gets the reſt, I'm like to be hamper'd my ſelf. By Cheapſide Conduit, I'm running mad; Horn-mad, by Bedlam Weather-cock. But Neceſſity has no Law. I muſt ſecure my Youngſter and my ſelf, and take the beſt Order for the reſt the little Brains I have will permit;

lg.l: And if I fruſtrate all their poiſonous Arts,
Why then Sir Fickle is a Man of Parts.

p.hi: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT V. Trulove and Wildman meeting.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: ONce more well met, I've been getting the Writings. Oh! I ſee you're likewiſe in Poſſeſſion, you have loſt no more time then my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not a minute. Delays in theſe Caſes are as dangerous as Diligence neceſſary. Had I not been aſſiduous, the Rogue might have relaps'd into Villany, and been true to his Truſt— But now for my Spouſe to be, methinks I would ſoon put an end to this ſame Affair; for I ſhall ne'er think her ſecure till I have her in the Laſh of Matrimony; beſides, Faith, I long to give the poor Rogue ſome hearty Proof of my Affection.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Somewhat too I have reſolv'd, which makes me uneaſie till it be put in Execution.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How, you!— Why, you have been ſo long us'd to dance Attendance, I dare have ſworn you'd have ſerv'd your full time, without repining, to have been made Free of the Corporation.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You're wide, Sir, you're wide.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Or rather ſhort, I believe; for you Archers of the Honourable Confraternity of blind Cupid, have ſuch damn'd long marks, that we poor Bow-men can't reach within a Score of your Butts—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Troth, like enough.
But here comes my Snow-ball rouling to way. Wou'd to Chance ſhe'd pick me up in her Paſſage, I'd thaw her with a Vengence, or ſhe ſhould freeze me to her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Your Servant, Gentlemen, how is't with ye ſince the laſt Surprize?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ſure I'm deaf, or ſhe's dim-ſighted.
As with a hungry Gueſt, when Dinner's on the Table, that curſes the grateleſs Chaplain for being out of the way, Madam.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: O! Sir, 'tis but a ſhort Collation of cold Meat; and there needs not ſo much Ceremony for that.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I know that, if I had but the Courage to fall on; but there's ſuch a damn'd many little Bones in the Pye, I'm affraid of being choak'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Therefore chew well before you ſwallow for good and all, Sir; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Chew, what, Madam? Oons! I'm none of your Camelions, to feed upon the Cud of a Wind-cholick Air.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But, by way of Paſtime, you might ſtand a little, and bite on the Bitt—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Like a Horſe, and break my Teeth like an Aſs— Conſolation and Preferment in abundance! Trepan my Pericranium— Madam, ſince you have no other Employment for me, than as a Poſt to fix your Jeſts on, I think I may, without Incivility, make bold to retire.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, why ſo haſty? Why, this is Volunteer-like; ſerve till you're on the Point of Promotion, and then quit your Poſt.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That, Madam, you can't blame me for, ſince the Fatigues I've under gone have diſabled me for further Service.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nay, then indeed I muſt look out for a freſh Man; yet, through Compaſſion, I'll not quite caſt you off, but keep you by me. Let's ſee, (opens his Mouth;) ay, in quality of a Nut cracker: Your Teeth are ſound enough yet, I ſee, if your Breath be but ſweet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oons, a Nut-cracker! what do you take me for a Monkey, Madam?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What, ſtill complain! Why, I've known many a Woman has put her Husband to a far worſe Employment.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, Madam, ſince you're in the vein, pray pleaſe your Fancy entirely; I have done.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And I, for this Bout.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I ſhall prevent the next.

sp.speaker: Let. to Tru.
sp.p: How, Sir, Penſive! when your Happineſs is ſo nigh. Sure, your overfaſting has ſpoil'd your Stomach; if ſo, I'll give you a Cordial ſhall retrieve it— Here, (Enter Singer) ſing the Song my Siſter made t'other Day.

l.hi: HOpe, thou Friend to the Diſtreſſed,
Kind Reviver of the Mind;
None that Hopes, can be oppreſſed:
Tho' Fortune frowns, thou'rt ever kind.
Hope, thou ſov'reign Eaſe to Grief,
Bleſs'd Encreaſer of our Joy,
Thou ſhouldſt have Proof, thou beſt Relief,
'Gainſt what would my Love deſtroy.
Welcome Hope, Adieu Deſpair,
The tott'ring Wheel at laſt will turn;
Tho' I languiſh for my Dear,
I'll not conſume, but ever burn.

lg.l: Tho' I languiſh, &c.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Well, Sir; this, I hope, has ſome Effect on you.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Medicines, Madam, are but at beſt caſt away, where the Malady of the Patient is miſapprehended.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I muſt confeſs your late Symptoms have been ſo ſtrange, that I cannot but gueſs your Diſtemper to be of the moſt unuſual.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: True, Madam, in the Age we live, but I have reap'd this Benefit by my Misfortune, to find the ſtrongeſt Paſſion too weak to withſtand a generous Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Your Words, Sir, are as myſterious as ever; but here comes your Cathollicon: If that does not work effectually, your Condition's deplorable indeed.
sp.stage: Enter Honoria, who runs and embraces Trulove.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O, my dear Trulove! thus let me embrace thee,
Thus let me claſp thee in my longing Arms,
(Kiſſing.) And thus cement our Hands, Lips, Hearts, together.
Pardon, if Love o'ercome my Modeſty;
For now I count you as my better Part.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Look down, ye Powers, and view this matchleſs Love.
Steal my faint Heart, direct my trembling Hand;
Aſſure my fault'ring Tongue, grant Strength of Mind
To act that which you only could inſpire.
With theſe take back your Vows; and with them mine,
May you be happier in a nobler He,
As far 'bove me, as is your Love and Honour:
Nay, by the Pains I feel, if it might be,
I'd wiſh him ſo divine as to deſerve you.
Then when I ſee you circl'd in his Arms,
Raviſh'd with Joys, diſſolv'd in Exſtaſie,
I'll ſend up Vows unenvious Vows to Heaven,
To make them infinite, your Loves eternal.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What can this mean! O my Prophetick Fears?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I mean you've truſted ſuch a Stock of Love
With one ſo far unable to requite it,
That it were Baſeneſs, beyond all Excuſe,
Still to run on when ſo much is unpay'd:
I mean to teach th' admiring Powers above,
My Gratitude's as great, more gen'rous than your Love.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hum— Why, I muſt confeſs this is ſomewhat ſurprizing. However, I ſhall rather imitate than diſcommend it— Here, Madam, (Gives the Papers to Let.) receive your own, and with them all I can call mine. My Heart's diſingag'd, my Affection entirely yours to bragg of; more, would be but to relapſe into what you have ſo ſeverely, but juſtly, reprov'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nay, now you're ſerious ſomewhat may be done: But I fear'd Capitulations before Surrender; which, if they had happen'd— But no more, hope well; you know I hear you're not indifferent to me, 'tis with Joy I own it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: This is too much— But ſee the fair Honoria
Bedew'd, and ſilent, as a Summer's Night.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Come, cheer up, Siſter: What, a-la-mort Woman, whining for a loſt Lover, when you have wherewithal to buy a Score of Husbands! But three Days Patience, and on my Life you'll have more Suitors than you'll diſpatch in three Months.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: No; may I live by all Mankind diſdain'd,
And die a wretched Object of Deſpair,
If e'er within this Heart I entertain
A ſecond Thought for any but my Truelove.
What tho' to you perchance he ſeem unkind,
Yet I, that view the Treaſures of his Mind
Adore him ſtill, as from the Powers above,
Take this Correction as a Sign of Love.
Nay, by my fleeting Love-ſick Soul I ſwear,
Should he be cold, nay farther yet ſevere,
The little ſpace then doom'd me for to live,
To th' pleaſing Thoughts of our paſt Loves I'd give:
Then, when you'd think that I forſaken lie,
You'd ſee my Trulove beg me not to die.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Cold Comfort, by my departing Maidenhead, Siſter, if this be all; but I hope there's warmer in ſtore.
You know, Sir, your Obligations to my Siſter; I need not tell you the Occaſions preſent, to require them, and oblige me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, I do as well as I am acquainted with his Temper. 'Tis honourable to Obſtinacy, but not perverſe to Reaſon. So good a Cauſe can never want a happy Iſſue— I go with Confidence of good Succeſs to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Unhappy Maid! what Crimes have I committed,
Doubly to ſuffer by Exceſs of Love?
Whom ſhall I accuſe? The Gods? Oh no,
They're Juſt, and Trulove is in Honour next 'em;
No, 'tis my Self, my Frowardneſs, my Pride,
Nay worſe,
My black Ingratitude to ſo much Love,
Has forc'd this unexampl'd Judgment on me.
Yet ſtill, methinks, I did but that which he
So lately and ſo ſtrictly did purſue,
As if h' had taken Copy from my Actions;
And he's too wiſe, nay, too divinely good,
To act or follow ought that is amiſs.
Heavens! in what a Lab'rinth am I got,
Lend me the Clew, or kindly end my Pain.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I hope they have heard you, look back.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Thus ſtubborn Criminals that Grace refuſe,
Trembling when late the proffer'd Mercy crave:
Sure 'twas ſome Evil Genius led me out
From Paradice, thus to run to my Deſtruction.
Yet you can pardon.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Unkind! thus to upbraid me with that Act,
That firſt was mine, by you but faintly trac'd;
Pardons for Crimes! You may command my Love;
If in Exchange you grant me yours, I'm bleſs'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Then, ye propitious Powers, ſmile kindly on us,
And yet prepare your direſt, worſt, Revenge,
If ought, ſave you, I like Honoria prize,
If next to you I do not her adore;
If her, whilſt Life, nay, after Death, I love not
With the ſame Paſſion that now fills my Breaſt.
And dart it down; nay worſe, be ſhe unkind.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: So much for that. Now, Madam, 'tis my turn;
If I perform it not with ſo much Zeal,
'Tis want of Words, not Paſſion, pleads Excuſe.
sp.p: Beſides: Faith, to tell you neatly my Mind, theſe far-fatch'd Expreſſions, and new-fangl'd ways of Courtſhip, become a Stage far better than a Lady's Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well, that I expect not, but this you muſt,
If I catch you in the old Haunt, or any where elſe.
But—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if I elope, bar me of my Thirds. I'm content, as to that Point, to reinverſe the Law, and become Baron-Covert.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Of your Thirds! Don't ſo much as expect a bare Allimony.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And, Faith, I'll ſay ſo much for my ſelf; if we're once join'd, I ſhall ne'er hope for a ſeparate Maintenance— Come, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: As for the reſt, I bring you a plentiful Fortune; and, as Jonathan ſays, a tite, neat, and convenient Tenement. Uſe me like a Gectleman, I entirely truſt in you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, give me your Hand—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And Heart are yours, from this Breath to my laſt.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: So, now the Storm's blown over, Sky's ſerene.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Come, no more Words, but produce.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not yet, Faith, I hear a grumbling thereaway; and I have a plaguy Opinion the Clap will fall ſomewhere hereabouts— Oh, here it comes with a Vengeance. Retire Trulove.
sp.stage: He goes aſide, and Enter Fickle and Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Tell me not of ſafe Cuſtody, or honeſt Hands; mine are the ſafeſt and honeſteſt too for my purpoſe. Therefore once more produce, or— (ſpies them.)— Oh Niece, have you conſider'd? And you, Mr. Wildman? I hope your Paſſion's over; How is't, ha?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, as my Wiſhes, but you ſeem ſomewhat troubled.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a little, not much neither. But this ſame Rogue, Dog, of a Jonathan would move a Saint— Your Mortgage, Sir, I'll reſign you up, as ſoon as that— will give me leave. Swine's Snout, be gone, and fetch it; no more grunting.
sp.stage: As Jonathan is going out, Trulove whiſpers him; and Exit Jon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall receive it with Thanks. One more Requeſt I muſt repeat; I'm ſure you have too much Good Nature to deny me. (Enter Eug.) Oh! here it is, you know my Meaning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Oh, the Devil! ſhe here!— Why, Sir, and you know mine; you'll find me no Changeling, tho' you deſign'd me for an aboriginal Cuckold, as Neighbour Wrangle calls it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nor me ſo tame a Coward to put up ſuch Affronts both to my Couſin and my ſelf! I'll waſh 'em off in thy degenerate Blood. (Wild. draws, the Women all run out, ſhrieking Murder! except Eugenia, who interpoſes.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh! ſpare my Love, or let us die together!

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Die together! No, nor lie together: If ye do, it may be in Bridewell, or Little-eaſe—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, Sir, reſolve to—

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Why ſo quick, Sir? If I muſt be executed, methinks you might grant me a Reprieve. Pray, Sir, conſider; were't your own Caſe, you'd not be ſo haſty.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, if Time be all you ask, take it, provided it be Reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: O, as for that matter, Sir, I only deſire juſt as much as to— (Running off, Wild. catches him) Murder! Murder! Jacobites! Papiſts! (ſhrilly) a Rape! a Rape! a Rape!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll cut your bellowing Bull's Throat.

sp.speaker: eug.
sp.p: laying hold on Wild. O! hold your Hand; for if he bleeds, I die.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: You Lye, you jilting Whore! you Lye.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! What e'er it be, it can't be brave, thus to aſſault a naked Man: If his Cauſe be Juſt, he ſhan't want one to defend it.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Ay, ay, (to him) Mr. Trulove, he's a Rogue, if not a Coward; here I've given him my Niece, and his mortgag'd Eſtate back, and he in Recompence would ſtick me like a Pig.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Then hear me too, ſince you will needs be Judge:
This Flatt'ring villain! For he is no better,
With Gifts, Oaths, Courtſhips, has allur'd my Couſin;
And now he finds ſhe loves, he ſlights her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Nay, there I leave your Cauſe, 'tis ſo unjuſt,
My Life I ne'er will venture to aſſert it;
Yet, that you may not die defenceleſs,
I'll lend you this.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Lend me your Sword! I'd as lieve you'd lend me a Halter. Sir, I'd have you to know I'm a good Chriſtian, and will keep the King's Peace. I fight! I'll be hang'd, nay, marry as ſoon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, then, thou Cheat! thou ignominious Knave!
Know I have found you out, and am poſſeſs'd
Of all Sir Roger's Papers, and my Mortgage.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Ruin'd! undone! like a Bundle of Licoriſh.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not all, Sir, by your Leave: I have my ſhare, and peruſing 'em over, I find an Account to be made, ſome Arrears of Inrereſt, and ſo forth, you know; and look to't, for I ſhall be ſevere.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Accounts to you! Why, what are you?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Honoria's Husband; and conſequently, as I take it, your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Over-reach'd again! (Aſide.) I knew, tho' I wink'd at it, he was playing thereabouts; but now the ſharking Dog has bit to the purpoſe, Hook and Bait, I' Faith, he has clear'd me of my Tackling.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not yet; but I think I ſhall, 'fore I've done, come in there.
sp.stage: Enter Lurcher and Jonathan, diſguis'd, like Bailiffs.
sp.p: Now do your Offices.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, I arreſt you in an Action of Account, at the Suit of Mr. Trulove.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: And I, Sir, in the ſame, at the Suit of Mr. Wildman.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Mine! What means this?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Rum dun done! Broke like a Barrel of Figs! For Pity ſake, hear me but a Word.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Be ſhort, Sir, I loſe time, and I've half a ſcore of your Neighbours to arreſt upon Change. Come, quick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Why then, Gentlemen, I acknowledge my ſelf a Villain to my Nieces, and not much better to Madam Eugenia: You have made your ſelf, in part, Satisfaction; but a little Patience, I'll endeavour to compleat it. Here, Honey, Honey; Why, Lettice? Lettice?
Pray, give 'em a Call. (Exit Lurcher.) Mean while I take this Lady to my Wife, if ſhe can forget my Ingratitude, it will be ſome Comfort in my • isfortunes to ſay, I was once Juſt in my Life.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And to me to ſhare in 'em as I have done in your Proſperity. This, Sir, I hope, will convince you that I love.
Better half a Loaf, than no Bread.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: I believe it, my Cinnamon-ſtick, tho' my Seeing and Hearing would be ſo impertinent as to convince me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, in matters of Faith and Love, we ought never to truſt too much to the Senſes. Curioſity and Jealouſie are good for nothing but to promote Heriſie and Cuckoldom.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Then, Sir, let the Simplicity of my Belief ſhew the vehemency of my Affection. Come, my All-ſpice, come.
If ſhe ben't as chaſte as her Neighbours, ſhe muſt feed upon Cantharides, and ſpend her Pinmoney in Chocolate.
sp.stage: Aſide. Enter Lurcher with Hon. and Letitia.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And my Liberality be the mark of my Affection: In Conſideration of your Complaiſance, and of Eugenia's Fortune, I freely forgive what Accompts may be between us; you ſhall have a Releaſe upon Demand, ſo my Letitia conſent.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: With Pleaſure, Sir; and not only that, but I'll join with my Siſter to mollifie Trulove.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your Entreaties, Ladies, would be needleſs; his Conſent is all I ſhall deſire in Requital.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Sir, you have it as freely as I can give it.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: And there's Four: What bloody Doings will there be to Night!

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: So this is pretty well, if it were not for thoſe Rogues the Bayliffs, that will blaze all about.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Who I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Yes, you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nor I, Sir.
You lie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nor I, Sir; by the Skie, Sir; let me die, Sir, if I lie, Sir: Why, Sir, I am no Mag-pye, Sir.
Jonathan and Lurcher!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: The ſame; I fearing Mr. Wildman would have been in earneſt, took this Courſe, both to ſurprize you agreeably, and prevent further miſchief.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, I muſt confeſs your Fate would have been ſomewhat ſevere, had you not been reaſonable— But I'm glad all's ended ſo fairly. As for them, a ſmall Spell will ſtop their Mouths, I don't doubt: Or at worſt, 'tis no ſtranger a thing for a Citizen to be a Cheat than a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Gibing!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, Forgiveneſs and the Twenty Pound a Year, is all I ask; you ſhall find me hereafter ſo faithful to deſerve it— But as for this ſlip, I proteſt, Sir, what with Over care and Over-faſting, Idea's of Stocks, Pillories, Whipping-poſts, and Qualms of Conſcience, I was ſo tormented in the Spirit, that it run me almoſt mad. Blanch me like an Almond, Sir, if I remember any thing of the matter, but the Twenty Pound a Year aforeſaid.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And the Civility-Money, Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, I have been told ſince, that I rav'd mightily of the Barbadoes Fleet, and Bird in Hand.
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Well, Friends of all ſides, I have yet Ten Thouſand Pound left me, out of which I'll allow you as I had determin'd, and put thee in preſent Poſſeſſion. Hang Dirt, I was almoſt choak'd with it, and now I'm eas'd, methinks I'm as brisk as—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Bottle-All, all Froth and Settlings.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee that preſently; I'll put your Agility to the Teſt for once. Strike up there.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nay, pray Gentlemen, not ſo haſty, I want a Companion: I'll out and lure her, ſhe'll come to Fiſt in a trice, and there will be no ſport till I come, as the Man ſaid when he was going to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's but reaſonable, th' haſt been ſo inſtrumental in the laſt Comedy, 'twere Ingratitude to leave thee out, now its come to a Concluſion.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: And prithee do you in and haſten Supper: I ne'er cou'd work well on an empty Stomach.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Mean time, if you pleaſe, I'll entertain you with a Song I lately compos'd, which is both inſtructive, and ſuitable to this preſent occaſion. Here
here, ſing this.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: By all means come; one Hawk, two Hums, and ſtart fair.
sp.stage: Whilſt the Song is a Singing, Enter Jon and Jenny.

div.head: A SONG. To be Sung betwixt a Man and a Woman.

l.hi: WHY ſo cruel to your Lover?
Oh, the hidden Cauſe declare!
'Twou'd be more cruel to diſcover
What muſt bring you to Diſpair
Men, like Salvage Beaſt's, Love ranging,
Here to day, and there at night;
All our Fears are in your changing
That your darling cheif Delight

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: All our Fears, &c.

l.hi: But ſo freſh a blooming Paſture.
Me for ever will encloſe;
You need fear no ſuch Diſaſter
When I change, I'm ſure to loſe.
He for ever will be kind,
Who in Love his profit finds.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: He for ever, &c.

l.hi: But when Envious Age at loſt
Has made all my Beauties bare;
Then, like Land, that lies at waſt,
You'll not judge me worth your Care,
No man thinks that worth his Pains,
Where's all Labour and no Gains.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: No man thinks, &c.

l.hi: To convince you I'll be kind,
I love where Time has no Controul,
'Tis the Beauty of your Mind
That has Charm'd my doating Soul:
As frail Beauty does decline,
Worth and Virtue briter ſhine.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: As frail Beauty, &c.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Come, once more all Friends; and to ſhew you how light what is paſt lies on my Heart, we'll have a Dance, and then—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sbud, Sir, what do you mean! Let's Sup orofs the Water, and Conſummate, or we ſhall ſet your Prentices ſo agog, they'll go out in a Party, and plunder all they meet, or run away from their. Aprons, and forfeit their Indentures.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Briskly perform'd! Honeſt Sir Fickle, Igad, thou'rt twenty Years younger than thou was't an Hour ago. Ah! this ſame Honeſty is Soveraign Geer! 'Tis the Beſt Hearts-Eaſe in Nature.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Then let thoſe that gluttle with their Store,
Strain'd from the Tears of Orphan's Blood o'th' Poor,
Suck on, and Leeches like, when over cramm'd—

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Crack in this World, and in the next be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: And thoſe that would be juſt, may Learn by thee,
That Honeſty's the ſureſt Policy
